fields.summary: Volume remains in DELETING state after euca-create-volume/euca-delete-volume test

components.name: Architecture
components.description: Used for Architecture Documentation new feature requests

fields.description:
When investigating EUCA-5130, it is really difficult to understand why information is stored in different tables in the eucalyptus_storage database.  For EUCA-5130, it would be important to understand the state transitions that a volume goes through for troubleshooting.  

For example, while checking out the eucalyptus_storage database, iscsivolume table, I saw the following:

{code}
eucalyptus_storage=# select * from iscsivolumeinfo;
                id                |   creation_timestamp    |  last_update_timestamp  |          metadata_perm_uuid          | version | lodev_name  |                l
ofile_name                 |   lv_name   |   pv_name   |   sc_name    | size | snapshot_of  |  status   |   vg_name   |  volume_name  | encryptedpassword | lun |      
              storename                     | storeuser  | tid | cleanup 
----------------------------------+-------------------------+-------------------------+--------------------------------------+---------+-------------+-----------------
---------------------------+-------------+-------------+--------------+------+--------------+-----------+-------------+---------------+-------------------+-----+------
--------------------------------------------+------------+-----+---------

What is really confusing here is the following:

* Why are lodev_name, lv_name, and vg_name populated when there isn't any correlating information on the SC itself?  Below is the output of lvdisplay, vgdisplay, tgtadm --lld iscsi --op show --mode target --debug, and losetup -a on the SC:

{code}
[root@viking-03 ~]# tgtadm --lld iscsi --op show --mode target --debug
ipc_mgmt_req 305: sent to tgtd 120
[root@viking-03 ~]# losetup -a
[root@viking-03 ~]# vgdisplay

* What are the state transitions that a volume/snapshot go through?  For example, on the CLC in the cloud-ouptut.log, I deleted a volume, and it went from EXTANT to ANNIHILATED.  If this is the case, where does ANNIHILATING come into play?  Is there any reason as to why we don't keep the ANNIHILATED state of the volume in the DB for a given amount of time before purging? fields.summary: Lack of Procedure Documentation Regarding Database Information Concerning Volumes, Snapshots
fields.environment: This environment was non-HA.  Would love to understand this information as it relates to HA SC when using the different Storage backends.
